The crown belonging to Empress Eugénie was found on the sidewalk...
articles.content:
Jewel Thieves Dropped This Crushed Crown as They Fled the Louvre. Now, the Historic Headdress Will Be Restored to Its Former Glory
The crown belonging to Empress Eugénie was found on the sidewalk after robbers made away with eight pieces of royal jewelry in October. Officials estimate that the repair will cost nearly $50,000
A historic crown damaged during the shocking October heist at the Louvre will be restored, officials at the Paris museum announced. Thieves crushed the crown while attempting to extract it from a too-small hole in its glass case—and then, as they fled the scene, they dropped it on the sidewalk.
The robbers broke into the museum’s jewelry-filled Apollo Gallery through a second-floor window on the morning of October 19, 2025. They stole eight pieces of royal jewelry, including items from the collection of Napoleon III and his wife, Eugénie.
Quick facts: Eugénie’s tiara
- One of the items stolen during the heist was the empress’ pearl and diamond tiara.
- In January, fashion designer Daniel Roseberry created a reimagined version of the missing tiara for Paris Haute Couture Week.
The thieves nearly made away with nine pieces, but during their escape, they dropped Eugénie’s ornate crown. Created for the Universal Exhibition in Paris in 1855, the crown was adorned with 56 emeralds, eight golden eagles and 1,354 diamonds.
The four men who carried out the heist have since been arrested, but the other jewels haven’t been found. The empress’ crown was the only stolen piece recovered on the day of the theft. According to a statement from the Louvre, it retains almost all of its ornamentation.
“All of the most important pieces, the diamonds and emeralds, are actually still there,” Louvre director Laurence des Cars told the broadcaster France Info in November, per the Associated Press’ Sylvie Corbet. “A few small pieces of diamonds are missing, but that’s about it. … One of the eight gold eagles on the crown is missing.”
The crown’s crushed appearance wasn’t caused by a drop to the ground. Des Cars told French senators on October 22 that the thieves used an angle grinder to cut through the Apollo Gallery’s glass cases, according to the Guardian’s Angelique Chrisafis. She added that the glass had been difficult to break, forcing the robbers to extract the jewels through a very small hole.
“The glass resisted … so objects were crushed as they were being pulled out,” Des Cars said, per the Guardian. That’s how Eugénie’s crown came to look like it had been stepped on. Still, the director said at the time, “Initial assessments suggest that a delicate restoration is possible.”
When the crown’s flexible, lightweight mount was deformed, one of its palm-shaped ornaments detached, per the statement. A fragment of the ornament was found near the display case that protected the crown in the Apollo Gallery. But because nearly all of its other pieces are still attached, the museum says the crown can be completely restored “without the need for reconstruction,” per a translation by Agence France-Presse. Experts will only have to reshape its framework.
“We’re going to set up a scientific committee to supervise the restoration, and it will be a beautiful symbol of the Louvre’s renaissance,” Des Cars told France Info.
The museum has assembled a team of advisers from its own staff and from other French museums, like the Musée d’Orsay and the National Museum of Natural History. The Louvre has also enlisted representatives from five historic French jewelry houses: Mellerio, Chaumet, Cartier, Boucheron and Van Cleef & Arpels. Olivier Gabet, the Louvre’s decorative arts director, tells the New York Times’ Catherine Porter that the restoration is estimated to cost about $47,000.
Napoleon III, the nephew of Napoleon Bonaparte, was the leader of France’s Second Empire. In the mid-19th century, he commissioned two crowns—one for himself and one for his wife—from the official royal jeweler, goldsmith Alexandre Gabriel Lemonnier. The crowns were to be displayed at the 1855 Universal Exhibition in Paris. The emperor had announced the event following the success of London’s Great Exhibition of the Works of Industry of All Nations in 1851.
Lemonnier enlisted the help of a sculptor and another jeweler to build the crowns. The headpieces complemented each other, but observers at the expo noted the empress’ crown was lighter than the emperor’s, per the statement. Eugénie died in 1920, and the Louvre acquired her crown in 1988. The piece is one of only three French rulers’ crowns still in France.
Gabet expects the crown will be restored by the end of the year. At that point, it will be publicly displayed “at the Louvre obviously,” he tells the Times. The decorative arts director hopes the crown’s missing pieces will eventually be recovered. The lost golden eagle “is probably somewhere with the other pieces that were stolen, and perhaps we will find them one day,” he says.

articles.content:
When Human Activity Dropped During Covid-19, Methane Emissions Surprisingly Spiked. Now, a Study Points to Two Reasons Why
In a paradox of air pollution, a decrease in man-made pollutants led to more methane in our atmosphere. And natural wetlands released more of the planet-warming gas at the same time
As the world shuttered in 2020 amid Covid-19 lockdowns, scientists expected to see one silver lining to the pandemic: a decrease in air pollution. With fewer cars on the roads and a drop in industrial activity, researchers did notice a dip in daily carbon dioxide emissions and other pollutants. But methane, the second-largest contributor to climate change, surprisingly surged to its highest levels in the atmosphere since researchers began measuring it in the 1980s.
Six years later, a team of more than 40 scientists has offered an answer to this chemical mystery in a study published last week in Science, pointing to dynamics in the atmosphere and natural areas.
“By providing the most up-to-date global methane budget through 2023, this research clarifies why methane rose so rapidly—and why it has recently slowed,” says Philippe Ciais, a researcher at France’s Laboratory for Climate and Environmental Sciences (LSCE) and lead author of the paper, in a statement from the European Space Agency.
When methane enters the atmosphere, it interacts with a molecule called the hydroxyl radical, which destroys the methane by converting it into less harmful gases. Hydroxyl radicals, though, have a very short lifespan and must be constantly replaced.
To create hydroxyl radicals, you need reactions between sunlight and various gases—including air pollutants emitted from manmade processes, such as nitrogen oxides. When less air pollution entered the atmosphere due to the 2020 lockdowns, it meant fewer hydroxyl radicals were being created, and they could not destroy as much methane.
This air pollution paradox—where less emissions of one pollutant meant that another remains in the atmosphere for longer—suggests that researchers must prioritize more nuanced tracking of atmospheric processes, says Clement Albergel, head of the ESA’s Actionable Climate Information section, who was not involved in the research, in the statement.
“The study underscores the growing importance of satellites—not only for tracking greenhouse gases, but for revealing the subtle chemical processes that govern their fate in the atmosphere,” Albergel adds. “It shows that climate surprises are not always about what we emit, but about how the atmosphere responds.”
Did you know? This satellite is tracking methane emissions
MethaneSAT, launched in 2024, measures methane emissions and tracks their sources using artificial intelligence. By zeroing in on oil and gas infrastructure and the agricultural sector, the satellite could pinpoint machinery that contributes to methane leaks.
Around 80 percent of the methane surge was a result of this pollutant reaction, the authors predict. But the rest primarily came from an increase in methane emissions, the work suggests, rather than a decrease in the atmosphere’s ability to destroy them.
Though manmade methane emissions dropped during the pandemic, methane is also released by natural sources, including wetlands. The early 2020s also coincided with La Niña, a periodic climate event that causes increased rainfall in tropical areas. As regions throughout Africa and Southeast Asia got wetter, they became more ideal environments for methane-producing microbes.
“As the planet becomes warmer and wetter, methane emissions from wetlands, inland waters and paddy rice systems will increasingly shape near-term climate change,” Hanqin Tian, an environmental scientist at Boston College and a co-author of the study, says in a statement from Boston College.
Both the increased natural production and the decreased natural destruction of methane described in the study are largely outside of human control, but the researchers urge a reduction in manmade emissions to offset these natural processes.
“For me, this means we need to improve air quality and, even more importantly, mitigate greenhouse gas emissions, to offset these negative effects linked to the chemical-climate relationship,” says Marielle Saunois, a researcher at LSCE and a co-author of the study, to the Agence France-Presse’s Julien Mivielle and Laurent Thomet.
Around 160 countries are part of the Global Methane Pledge, an initiative launched in 2021 to cut methane emissions by 30 percent by 2030. Though methane is second to carbon dioxide in its contributions to climate change and has a shorter lifespan in the atmosphere, it has a more potent warming effect.
To explain the methane surge and create a “global methane budget,” which tracks the amount of methane added and removed from the atmosphere, the researchers brought together observations from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, data from the GOSAT satellite and various computer models.
“This paper really highlights the success of all these multitiered methods that we’ve developed as a community,” says Francesca Hopkins, a climate change scientist at University of California, Riverside, who was not involved in the work, to Fionna Samuels at Chemical and Engineering News. She adds that “the whole globe relies on these datasets.”

articles.title: This Scientist Brewed and Drank His Own 'Vaccine Beer' to Combat a Dangerous Virus. It Seems to Have Worked
articles.author: Redação

Blood tests revealed that the beverage elicited an immune response, according to...
articles.content:
This Scientist Brewed and Drank His Own ‘Vaccine Beer’ to Combat a Dangerous Virus. It Seems to Have Worked
Blood tests revealed that the beverage elicited an immune response, according to preliminary research. But far more safety and efficacy testing would be needed before this vaccine could become available
Many people dread needles and fear the brief discomfort of getting injected with a vaccine. But what if the process could be as painless—and even as enjoyable—as drinking a pint of beer?
Virologist Christopher Buck recently tested the idea on himself with “vaccine beer” that he homebrewed with engineered yeast. The beer contained signals that tell the immune system to raise its guard against BK polyomavirus, which can cause kidney, bladder, brain and cardiovascular diseases. The unorthodox immunization seems to have heightened his body’s defenses against the pathogen, according to a study exploring edible vaccines posted in December on the research repository website Zenodo. It has not been peer-reviewed.
“The idea really is to just take living yeast, which are what makes beer, and put a vaccine inside the living yeast. And by doing that, you can actually get the yeast to cause an immune response,” says Buck, who works at the National Cancer Institute but is conducting the beer project as an independent researcher, in a video. “It’s a radically simplified approach to making vaccines.”
During previous experiments, Buck and his colleagues fed mice live yeast containing empty particles that resemble BK polyomavirus, reports Science News’ Tina Hesman Saey. Those particles had formed because the researchers had supplied the yeast with genetic instructions to make a protein found in the pathogen’s outer shell. Surprisingly, after chowing down on the particles, the animals’ bodies made BK-polyomavirus-fighting antibodies.
The team’s analyses suggest that live yeast protects viral proteins from stomach acid, allowing them to reach the intestines, where immune cells can learn to recognize them, Buck and another independent researcher—his brother—write in a different study that describes the beer-making process. It was also posted on Zenodo in December and has not been peer-reviewed.
“I’ve homebrewed beer off and on for 30 years. When I saw that feeding lab mice with engineered brewer’s yeast could induce protective antibody responses against the virus I study, my instant first thought was, ‘Well, I can definitely do that at home,’ Buck writes in a blog post.
And that’s exactly what he did—in his own kitchen. “It was one of the best homebrews I ever made,” Buck tells the London Times’ Will Pavia.
For five consecutive days in May, Buck drank one pint of the vaccine beer. He took a five-day booster dose seven weeks later, followed by another seven weeks after that. Blood tests indicated that after downing the drinks, Buck produced antibodies for two kinds of BK polyomavirus thought to be implicated in some bladder cancers, he tells the London Times. In the beer-making study, Buck and his brother also report no significant side effects.
The approach, however, has caused a bit of a stir. Buck skirted around a National Institutes of Health (NIH) research ethics committee’s decision that he couldn’t test the vaccine beer on himself by starting a nonprofit organization called Gusteau Research Corporation, according to Science News. This work as a private citizen is beyond the NIH committee’s purview.
Fun fact: Who’s Gusteau?
The company was named for chef Auguste Gusteau, a character in the animated film Ratatouille, per Science News. The fictional chef’s slogan was “Anyone can cook.”
And some researchers criticize the work. Michael Imperiale, a virologist at the University of Michigan Medical School who wasn’t involved with the research, tells Science News that the beer approach would need much more safety and efficacy testing, and that it wasn’t clear which possible side effects Buck and his colleagues were looking for.
Arthur Caplan, a medical ethicist at the New York University Grossman School of Medicine who also wasn’t involved, tells the outlet that the idea of vaccine beer could worsen growing antivaccine sentiments. “This is not the place for do-it-yourself.”
Still, Buck and his colleagues think that edible vaccines could pave a new path. Beer isn’t the only option, either—any food with the engineered live yeast could be an immunization option, the Buck brothers say in the video.
“Food-based vaccines are dramatically faster, easier and cheaper to produce and are less painful than traditional injection vaccines,” the authors of the edible vaccines study write. “For some populations, edible vaccines may also be more acceptable and accessible than existing pharmaceutical products.”
What’s more, the researchers hope to expand to other diseases. “This one vaccine is just proving the principle,” Buck tells the London Times. “Next on the agenda is Covid and flu and probably herpesviruses and adenovirus [which typically causes cold or flu symptoms] … Anything that is a common-cold virus is in our crosshairs now.”

articles.content:
How a Little-Known French Region Safeguarded the Louvre’s Treasures During World War II
More than 3,000 artworks from national museums were stowed in chateaus in the Lot—about 350 miles south of Paris
There’s little fanfare at the entrance to Château de Montal, outside the village of Saint-Jean-Lespinasse in southwest France. In fact, as I arrive one Saturday afternoon in October, more cars are parked in a lot for the modern golf course that has sprung up near it than at the 16th-century castle obscured behind a curtain of oak trees.
Built for Jeanne de Balsac, Lady of Montal, between 1519 and 1534, Château de Montal is one of the rare early French castles to be commissioned by a woman. The daughter of Robert de Balsac, a knight and chamberlain to King Charles VIII, Jeanne was left to raise five children alone when her husband, Amaury de Montal, died in 1510.
The chateau’s early Renaissance style marked a transition from the medieval fortresses that dot a landscape so keenly fought over by the English and French during the Hundred Years’ War. Chiseled out of stone, the ornate busts of de Balsac’s family members hang beneath Sleeping Beauty-style turrets. The architecture also tells the story of grief. “Her eldest son, and heritor, Robert, died on the battlefield on a military campaign in Italy in 1523. She talks of her pain as a mother in the decoration,” says Sylvie Dusséaux, the deputy administrator of Château de Montal. The phrase plus d’espoir, or “no more hope,” is engraved into one of the stones.
The castle passed to her descendants upon her death in 1559 and was eventually abandoned in the late 1800s, when many of its architectural features were stripped and sold at auction. In the early 20th century, Maurice Fenaille, a French patron of the arts, purchased the chateau. “He invested colossal resources into the restoration, including setting out to buy back the pieces that had been sold at auction,” says Dusséaux. He managed to recoup 85 percent of the facade’s original sculptures. He commissioned the workshop of his friend, the artist Auguste Rodin, to create copies from plaster of those he couldn’t. Fenaille donated the chateau to the French state in 1913, while securing the right to continue living there for himself and his children. After decades of welcoming public visits only over the summer months, it opened to the public full-time in 2006.
Despite its fairy-tale silhouette and fascinating history, I’m not surprised to find myself among only a few people onsite as I walk through the rooms and garden at my own pace on a self-guided visit. Although Château de Montal is in France’s Dordogne Valley—named for the river that serpentines through it and famous as the land of 1,001 castles and for the prehistoric cave art at Lascaux—it’s in an area less frequented by tourists: the Lot.
More than 350 miles south of Paris, the Lot is one of France’s uncharted corners, despite exporting the inky red grape that grows from its soil, Malbec, to the world. Named for another river that flows through it, the Lot is also one of the country’s smaller departments: At a little over 2,000 square miles, it’s almost half the size of its better-known neighbor, the Dordogne department.
For more than two years at the end of World War II, from March 1943 until June 1945, however, the low-key setting of the Lot—and Château de Montal in particular—was exactly what was needed to answer a question Louvre curators had found themselves asking since before the war started: How do you solve a problem like the Mona Lisa?
Keeping the Mona Lisa safe
October 2025’s theft of €88 million ($102 million) worth of crown jewels from the Louvre shone a spotlight on how priceless the museum’s collection is not only in monetary value, but also in its role in French culture.
That’s why, as early as 1933, detailed plans were already underway to safeguard the collection should another war break out in Europe. “Multiple high-level authorities were involved, including the ministre de l’interieur [minister of the interior] and the ministre de l’education nationale [minister of national education], whose purview included the French national museums and thus the Louvre,” explains Gerri Chanel, author of Saving Mona Lisa, a comprehensive account of how the Louvre and its treasures were saved from the Nazis.
Everything owned by the Louvre, as well as other national museums, was protected under the Hague Conventions, written in 1899 and 1907. While that meant the Germans couldn’t freely help themselves to French public works of art, these laws of war couldn’t shield the art from the threat of destruction or looting.
In total, 5,667 crates from the national museums were evacuated from Paris starting September 1, 1939, the day Germany invaded Poland. At the Louvre, only the most fragile or bulky works of art were left in place. “The curators made detailed lists indicating the priority by which works should be evacuated,” says Chanel. A simple coding system was settled upon: A yellow dot was placed on most works, a green dot on works of major importance and a red dot for the most significant. Overseeing it all was the director of the national museums, Jacques Jaujard. “His heroism in protecting the Louvre’s artwork and antiques was extraordinary,” says Chanel.
In its purpose-built velvet-lined case inside a crate marked with little more than the letters MNLP0 (for Musées Nationaux Louvre Peintures No. 0) and three red dots—the only artwork to have been codified of utmost importance—“La Joconde,” as the French refer to Leonardo da Vinci’s most famous work, crisscrossed the country in the attempt to distance it from conflict, finding long-term safety in the Musée Ingres Bourdelle in the southwestern town of Montauban in October 1940. This was its fourth “safe house” after leaving Paris just over a year earlier.
By 1942, however, France in its entirety was occupied by the Germans (and Italians, in the southeast), and Montauban, with its strategically important location on the railroad just north of Toulouse, was no longer the haven it had once been.
Did you know? The Louvre is upgrading its security
“The aim was to stay as far away as possible from combat zones and from places that represented a military threat, particularly railway lines and sites linked to targets the army might want to bomb,” explains Ophélie Jouan, a Paris-based art historian.
Neighboring Lot, with its medieval castles, many isolated in forests, became the refuge that curators so desperately needed. The Mona Lisa, along with 1,300 other artworks, was sent to Château de Montal. Some 3,000 artistic treasures, including the Seated Scribe, the pride of the Louvre’s Egyptology collection, were concealed in seven other chateaus in the region’s thick woodlands, which also camouflaged France’s growing Resistance movement.
“These were places that were accessible by road but nevertheless away from main arteries,” Jouan says.
Louvre-sur-Lot
Today, Château de Montal is decorated with period furnishings acquired by Fenaille, such as tapestries, long banquet tables and four-poster beds. Sweeping stone staircases lead to a grand hall and bedrooms with vaulted ceilings and splendid stone fireplaces that overlook ornamental gardens. Explanatory signs are discreet, but tell the early history of the property, with much emphasis on Fenaille’s role in reviving it.
In the attic, a permanent exhibition chronicles the extraordinary two years of the “Louvre-sur-Lot,” as the era between 1943 and 1945 is colloquially referred to in the region. Through archival photographs and documents, as well as a short video, visitors learn that the ground-floor rooms were once jammed with 100 crates of art, including works by Antoine Watteau, Tintoretto and Édouard Manet. So necessary was every inch of space that some crates were stored behind heavy tapestries that still hang on the walls.
The Mona Lisa was set apart, its crate placed closest to the exit so it could be easily evacuated if necessary. It was constantly under watch—a bed set up next to it meant that even when guards were asleep, La Joconde was still within reach.
Like other “depots,” or art safe houses, during the war, Montal had a Louvre curator overseeing operations: Réné Huyghe. Across Montal and its four nearby satellite depots, he managed a team of 37 people and around–the-clock surveillance. Huyghe and his crew feared bombings and on-the-ground raids, not to mention normal wear on the artworks.
“Preservation in castles, abbeys and old stone buildings that were cold and damp was obviously not ideal,” says Jouan. The effect of humidity or moisture on the works was a constant worry—as was fire, accidental or otherwise. Curators constantly monitored the crates for signs of damage and organized routine fire drills. Thankfully, such catastrophes were never realized. In Montal, the Mona Lisa had found a place to see out the war.
Château de la Treyne and the “Seated Scribe”
Among the other chateaus in the Lot to shelter cultural treasures evacuated from Paris were Château de Béduer, which concealed much of the French film archives and now is the site of a popular women-only summer camp, Camp Château, and Château de la Treyne, which sits on a scenic bend of the Dordogne River outside the village of Lacave. Unlike Château de Montal, which belonged to the state, both properties were privately owned—Béduer by Jeanne Loviton, a lawyer and writer better known by her pen name, Jean Voilier, and la Treyne by the Fontana family from Spain.
Lucie Mazauric, who worked in the archives at the Louvre, spent April 1943 to November 1945 at la Treyne, alongside her husband, Louvre curator and author André Chamson, and their teenage daughter, Frédérique. They watched over 80 crates, mostly from the Egyptian Antiquities Department. The most precious artwork under their watch was the famous Seated Scribe, which dates from 2,500 B.C.E. (making it more than 4,500 years old). Discovered in Saqqara in 1850, the funerary relic of a cross-legged man writing on a roll of papyrus is made of limestone and reflects literate officials’ high rank in ancient Egyptian society.
In her memoir, Ma Vie de Châteaux, Mazauric describes la Treyne as “not very beautiful.” But in the decades since the war, the chateau has been carefully restored and is now a high-end hotel. As we pull into the driveway after the 45-minute drive from Montal, I feel like I’ve arrived on a medieval-film set. My 8-year-old daughter proclaims our top-floor room, which feels like a Rapunzel tower with views across the entire estate, the best hotel room she’s ever stayed in. She proceeds to disappear into the cubby purpose-built for kids and draw for most of the afternoon.
“People love hearing the story that this small statue [the Seated Scribe] was once in our home in la Treyne,” owner Stéphanie Gombert tells me. The property was purchased by the family of her husband, Philippe, in the 1980s and opened as a guest house before the couple took over ownership and transformed it into a five-star Relais & Châteaux property with a Michelin-starred restaurant that’s been helmed by the same chef, Stéphane Andrieux, for nearly 30 years.
No tangible evidence of the chateau’s Louvre-sur-Lot history remains for hotel guests to experience today, although Gombert has named a second-floor guest room “Scribe.” Hanging in its bathroom is a gouache painting the couple had made of the Seated Scribe.
Gombert learned that the presence of such works in the area was never a secret to locals. “People here knew, and they were proud,” she says. “The castle, in a way, belonged to them. Of course, it was private, but it was their place, too. It had to be defended at all costs.”
Hiding Rothschild art
While speculation on what works of national importance might be hidden nearby was likely popular at local farmers markets and village cafés, what wasn’t known was that la Treyne was also hiding some of the most valuable privately owned art in the world.
If the state’s collection was protected under the Hague Conventions, fair game in Nazi minds were the personal collections of wealthy Jewish families, such as the Rothschilds, a prominent European Jewish banking family. Amassed over generations, and reflecting a deep commitment to cultural patronage, their art collection included Old Master paintings, Renaissance sculptures, medieval manuscripts and decorative furniture. The Nazis looted more than 5,000 objects from various Rothschild collections during the war. That figure might have been higher, had it not been for Mazauric and Chamson, who, upon hearing that about 29 crates of Rothschild art were hiding in a prison deep in France’s Lozère region, undertook a journey to rescue them.
“They forged documents, making it look as if the Rothschild family’s collection was part of the national collection, and that’s how they managed to conceal them,” explains Benôit Kwietniak, a Lozère archivist who has documented this little-known chapter of history. The couple’s goal was simple: to include these works in all official inventories from la Treyne shared with the Kunstschutz, the Nazi department charged with protecting art during the war.
That’s how they safeguarded a veritable treasure chest of canvases, furniture and objects of art. “There was a Picasso, a Degas, three Rembrandts, three Renoirs, two Fragonards and two Watteaus among them,” says Kwietniak.
What’s more, not a single work was lost. “Everything was returned to the family at the end of the war,” he says. In a poetic footnote, the Louvre bought one of the pieces, the 18th-century Tabatière du Duc de Choiseul, or Choiseul snuffbox, in 2023 for €3.9 million ($4.6 million).
Heading home
After the war ended, the national works were similarly eventually repatriated to their original museums from their temporary homes in the Lot.
“It took time, for various reasons,” says Jouan. The France that emerged from the war was very different from the country it was before conflict broke out. “There were very limited resources, and the population was completely exhausted,” she adds.
The end of the war did not suddenly mean that money, fuel or vehicles were available. Rationing was still in place, and the winter of 1946 was extremely cold. “Sometimes it was preferable to keep the artworks where they were until the means existed to bring them back safely,” says Jouan—especially considering that no coal was available to warm the galleries at the Louvre, which wouldn’t truly reopen until 1947.
Before the collection returned home, the Louvre temporarily exhibited 13 canvases—among them Tintoretto’s self-portrait, Watteau’s La Finette and Jean Clouet’s portrait of François 1er—in Cahors, the biggest town in the Lot, to thank the local population for keeping such tokens of national heritage safe.
Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of this story is that despite the constant threat swirling around them, every single one of the 3,000-plus artworks that were safeguarded in the Lot returned to Paris, an achievement highly unlikely had it not been for the bravery of the Louvre’s curators who acted as sentinels for the duration of the war.
“We don’t really realize the level of risk that was taken at the time by the curators in order to protect the works of art,” says Jouan. Some, including Chamson, also became active members of the Resistance. “They went beyond their official duties as museum curators. They committed themselves body and soul.”
